results.title: David and Jennifer Learn Their Kerb Drill
results.creator_credit: Rhonda Small, John Martin-Jones, Australian Commonwealth Film Unit and Australian Road Safety Council
results.brief_description: David and Jennifer are sent on messages to a shop across a busy street. Their mother carefully explains the meaning of the traffic lights. They sing a safety song to remember the newly learnt rules.

results.title: David and his mother (from David Copperfield)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Tales from Charles Dickens”.
Excerpts from Charles Dickens’ “David Copperfield”. Describes the early years of David Copperfield from his life with his widowed mother and servant Peggotty, through his adjustment to his mother’s marriage to Mr Murdstone, until the time of his mother’s death and his enrolment at boarding school.

results.title: David and Hazel: a story in communication
results.creator_credit: John Howe, Nicholas Balla and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A study of what may happen when a husband insulates his job from his family. David believes that what happens at work is his sole concern. Hazel has grown to accept her husband’s estimation of himself as a breadwinner and of herself as homemaker, and does not expect his confidences when things go wrong. A neighbour voices quite different views about the sharing of family problems. When David’s job is threatened, it is from this neighbour that Hazel hears of it. Her worries, added to David’s, trigger a chain of reaction of bruised feelings. Presented as a case study for discussion on family relations.
results.title_for_label: David and Hazel: a story in communication
results.creator_credit_for_label: John Howe, Nicholas Balla and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: David and Dora married (from David Copperfield)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Tales from Charles Dickens”.
Excerpts from Charles Dickens’ “David Copperfield”. Tells how David and Dora’s idyllic existence begins to wane after their marriage because of Dora’s childlike inexperienced management of the household. Records the disastrous dinner for the uncomplaining Traddles, and the couple’s first quarrel. Shows how David’s acceptance of Dora’s ineptness affords them some final months of happiness before her death.

results.title: David and Dora (from David Copperfield)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Tales from Charles Dickens”.
Excerpts from Charles Dickens’ “David Copperfield”. David’s courtship of Dora is marked by great tenderness, amusing misunderstandings and treachery by Miss murdstone, who has re-appeared as Dora’s maid. Due to his aunt’s financial distress, it looks as though David will never marry Dora. But fate intervenes, and when Dora’s father dies leaving her penniless, David and Dora are free to marry.

results.title: David and Betsey Trotwood (from David Copoperfield)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Tales from Charles Dickens”.
Excerpts from Charles Dickens’ “David Copperfield”. Shows the change in Betsy Trotwood’s feelings toward David Copperfield, from her outrage at the time of his birth to her protectiveness of David against the unpleasant Murdstones some years later, in spite of her dislike of donkeys and small boys.

results.title: Date with Dizzy
results.creator_credit: John Hubley, Jim Di Gangi and Hubley Films
results.brief_description: A gentle satire on television commercials showing the production and use of effective advertising. Features Dizzy Gillespie and Quintet improvising a musical soundtrack for drawings made by John Hubley and his staff as they create animated-cartoon television commercials for a new product with unsuccessful results until the director screens three previous advertisements as examples of the desired effect. Concludes with a wild jam session led by Dizzy Gillespie. Several of the Hubley animation techniques are illustrated making this film useful for discussion on film technique.
results.creator_credit_for_label: John Hubley, Jim Di Gangi and Hubley Films

results.title: Date of birth
results.creator_credit: Donald Fraser, Michael Spencer and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A tribute to the older worker’s high standard of dependability and productivity, and a plea to employers to remove age barriers in hiring new staff. The bitter disappointment felt by an able man denied work because he is over forty-five is expressed in a brief dramatic sequence, and then the film presents the actual record of employees in this age group, reminding us that there is less absenteeism, a lower turnover rate and an equal standard of production among older workers. The importance to the whole country of giving a fair chance to workers over forty-five years of age is explained, and ways in which their problem is being tackled are described.

results.title: Data processing: an introduction
results.creator_credit: Dick Larson and Coronet Instructional Films
results.brief_description: Introduces the basic data processing functions of sorting data, collating material and calculating, beginning with manual methods and moving into punched card equipment. With electronic computer systems, we learn ways of increasing the speed and flexibility of processing, resulting in faster ways of handling greater quantities of data.
